required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.official_title: The Augmented Versus Routine Approach to Giving Energy Trial Metabolic Effects Sub-study (TARGET-ME)

lead_sponsor.agency: Australian and New Zealand Intensive Care Research Centre

clinical_study.source: Australian and New Zealand Intensive Care Research Centre

brief_summary.textblock: The estimation of calorie needs during routine practice in critically ill patients is highly variable and the thermogenic effect of continuous delivery of enteral nutrition (EN) on overall calorie utilisation in critically ill adults is unknown. The TARGET-ME study is a substudy of the TARGET trial (NCT02306746). The TARGET trial provides the perfect opportunity to measure calorie utilisation via indirect calorimetry (IC) and ventilator-derived carbon dioxide production (VCO2) to compare measured calorie utilisation to estimation methods, determine the potential thermic effect of EN solutions with different energy concentrations and investigate any associations with outcome.

primary_outcome.description: Difference in mean calorie delivery and mean measured calorie utilisation over the study period (expressed as a percentage of measured requirements received) in each study group

secondary_outcome.measure: Calorie difference in kcal in the whole study cohort
secondary_outcome.description: Calorie difference in kcal between mean calorie delivery and mean measured calorie utilisation over the study period (expressed as a percentage of measured requirements received) in the whole study cohort

other_outcome.description: Calorie difference in kcal between mean measured calorie utilisation and mean calorie requirements predicted by the estimation method used in TARGET and in routine clinical practice
Energy balance in both the intervention and standard care groups (with measured calorie utilisation as the reference) up until 4 weeks post randomisation
measured as the difference between mean measured calorie utilisation in kcal between the two intervention groups

other_outcome.measure: Correlation of energy expenditure (EE) assessed by IC and VCO2 compared to predictive equations estimates of EE
other_outcome.description: Correlation (bias, precision, accuracy rates) of EE assessed by IC and VCO2 compared to predictive equations estimates of EE

arm_group.description: Enteral (EN) feed 1.5 kcal/mL. Indirect calorimetry and/or VCO2 measurements will be taken periodically while in the TARGET main study

arm_group.arm_group_label: Active Comparator: TARGET protocol EN 1.0 kcal/mL
arm_group.description: Enteral feed 1.0 kcal/mL Indirect calorimetry and/or VCO2 measurements will be taken periodically while in the TARGET main study

study_pop.textblock: Adult critically ill patients who are mechanically ventilated

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
Patients must first meet the inclusion and none of the exclusion criteria for the TARGET main trail (NCT02306746). The following additional criteria applies for this study when indirect calorimetry is being used:
- Within 48 hours of randomisation to TARGET (first measurement only)
- Fi02 < 50% for the past 1 hour
- Positive end expiratory pressure (PEEP) < 12 mmHg for the past 1 hour
- The IC test can be conducted within 48 hours of randomisation to TARGET
- The patient is not considered agitated using the usual site assessment
- There is a clinician available to complete the test
Exclusion Criteria:
- There is an air leak in the ventilation circuit (ie bubbling inter-costal catheters, cuff leak at the endotracheal tube
- The patient is receiving renal replacement therapy or extracorporeal membrane oxygenation at the time of measurement
- Has had surgery in the last 6 hours (if enough time within the 48 hour window, consider waiting until this criteria is less than 6 hours)
- If the patient has a traumatic brain injury, for the previous 6 hours, their intracranial pressures have been unstable and in the opinion of the treating intensivist are not controlled
- The treating clinician believes that the IC test will pose risk to the patient

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: Australian and New Zealand Intensive Care Research Centre
